results.title: L'argent = Money
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Baste, Patricia Moraz and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description:
A single forged banknote changes hands as a schoolboy prank and follows a remorseless path (the chain reaction of Tolstoy’s novella) which culminates in murder. Bresson ignores sociological and psychological explanation in austerely charting the paradoxical path of crime and punishment which leads the murderer towards redemption. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Jean-Pierre Baste, Patricia Moraz ; director, writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Emmanuel Manchuel, Pasqualino de Santis ; music, Jean-Sebastien Bach ; editor, Jean-Francois Naudon.
Cast: Christian Patey, Caroline Lang, Silvie van den Elsen, Vincent Risterucci.

results.title: L'apprenti Salaud = the Apprentice Heel
results.brief_description:
Antoine was a pleasant and agreeable man for years, until a small inheritance begins to give him some dangerous ideas about gaining wealth and women. Partly in order to win the affections of a young woman, he becomes a small-time con man on the basis of some ideas his accountant has planted in his mind.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writer, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Georges Bizet.
Cast: Robert Lamoureux, Christine Dejoux, Claude Pieplu, Georges Wilson, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Jean-Francois Derec, Bernard Lavalette, Annick Blancheteau.

results.title: L'annee Derniere a Marienbad = Last Year in Marienbad (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment and Alain Resnais
results.brief_description:
Robbe-Grillet described ‘Marienbad’ as ‘the story of a persuading’ centred on a romantic triangle ending in violence, constructed in the mind of X, one of the three. To Resnais, ‘Marienbad’ looks like a statue and sounds like an opera’. The images of the chateau are those of a labyrinth of fake trails, variants, failures and repetitions, destroying spatial and temporal logic in a film about the processes of memory that locates everything in the present tense. In keeping with Robbe-Grillet’s rejection of conventional interior monologue the emphasis is not on what X is thinking and feeling but on what he ‘sees’. With a hint of playfulness Resnais’ treatment of Robbe-Grillet’s script suggests a meditation on narrative tyranny, a modernist demonstration of narrative cinema as process: instead of the image revealing the world, it reveals itself. Awards: Best Film Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1961 ; Prix Georges Melies 1961 ; Prix Andre Bazin 1961.

Credits: Producers, Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment ; director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Francis Seyrig ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier ; assistant director, Volker Schloendorff.
Cast: Giorgio Albertazzi, Delphine Seyrig, Sacha Pitoeff.

results.title: L'angleterre D'elizabeth = Elizabethan England
results.brief_description:
Episode 16 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Elizabeth I becomes Queen at 25. Her 39 articles lay the foundation for the Anglican church. Declared a heretic by the Pope, she also has to battle with Spain for naval supremacy. Other topics include: the beginning of circumnavigation, the voyages of Sr Francis Drake and the settlement of North America.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'Ange
results.creator_credit: INA France, Kira BM Films and Patrick Bokanowski
results.brief_description: This amazing marriage of art, music and film took five years (1977-1982) in the making by its French creator, Patrick Bokanowski and programmed non-stop in a Tokyo cinema for nearly ten years. The impressionistic images are accompanied by a beautiful atmospheric soundtrack of original music composed by Michele Bokanowski to present a textured, multi-layered complexity of vision and sound. “L’Ange” makes for compelling viewing and deserves its cult status in the world of avant-garde filmmaking. Cast includes Jacques Faure, Martine Couture, Jean-Marie Bon, Dominique Lesourd, Maurice Baquet, Rita Renoir, Patricia Peretti.

results.title: L'amoureuse = Women in Love
results.brief_description:
Nine women gather in a seaside home to discuss life, love, and the search for men in this routine comedy. The hostess leaves after her boyfriend calls her up, and one of the others picks up an American tourist at a local bar. She confiscates his passport to keep him for her temporary toy boy.

Credits: Director, Jacques Doillon ; writers, Jacques Doillon, Jean-Francois Goyet ; photography, Caroline Champetier ; music, Les Rita Mitsouko.
Cast: Marianne Denicourt, Aurelle Doazan, Catherine Bidaut, Helene de Saint Pere.

results.title: L'amour Par Terre = Love on the Ground
results.brief_description:
Playwright Clement Roquemaure attends the private performance of one of his plays. He then invites the actresses, Charlotte and Emily, to act in a yet to be completed play in his appartment and for a selected audience. A magician named Paul is Clement’s current live-in lover. After the actresses arrive, they find themselves influenced by Paul’s magic and start to see their future, while the story they are enacting stays fairly close to Clement’s own life.

Credits: Producer, Martine Marignac ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jacques Rivette, Marilu Parolini, Pascal Bonitzer, Suzanne Schiffman ; photography, William Lubtchansky, Caroline Champetier ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky ; sound, Pierre Gamet.
Cast: Geraldine Chaplin, Jane Birkin, Andre Dussolier, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Facundo Bo, Laszlo Szabo.

results.title: L'amour Nu = Naked Love
results.creator_credit: Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi and Yannick Bellon
results.brief_description:
Claire, a UNESCO interpreter, meets Simon, an oceanographer at an international conference. They fall in love and contemplate life together, but Claire finds a suspicious lump in her breast. After a few trips to the doctor, she finds out that she needs a mastectomy. Unable to announce the truth to her new boyfriend, she breaks off their relationship.

Credits: Producers, Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi ; director, Yannick Bellon ; writers, Yannick Bellon, Francoise Prevost ; photography, Jean Charvein ; music, Richard de Bordeaux.
Cast: Marlene Jobert, Jean-Michel Folon, Zoriza Lozic, Georges Rouquier, Hyppolite Girardot.

results.title: L'amour Fou = Mad Love
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jacques Rivette
results.brief_description:
“Rightly described by Dave Kehr as Jacques Rivette’s ‘breakthrough film, the first of his features to employ extreme length (252 minutes), a high degree of improvisation, and a formal contrast between film and theater,’ this rarely screened 1968 masterpiece is one of the great French films of the 60s. It centers on rehearsals for a production of Racine’s Andromaque and the doomed yet passionate relationship between a director and his actress wife, who leaves the production at the beginning of the film and then festers in paranoid isolation. The rehearsals, filmed by Rivette (in 35-millimeter) and by TV documentarist Andre S. Labarthe (in 16mm), are real, and the relationship between Kalfon and Ogier is fictional, but this only begins to describe the powerful interfacing of life and art that takes place over the film’s hypnotic, epic unfolding. In the rehearsal space Rivette cuts frequently between the 35- and 16-millimeter footage, juxtaposing two kinds of documentary reality; in the couple’s apartment, filmed only in 35, the oscillation between love and madness, passion and mistrust, builds to several terrifying and awesome climaxes in which the distinctions between life and theater, reality and fiction, become virtually irrelevant. In many ways this is Ogier’s richest, finest performance, and Kalfon keeps pace with her every step of the way. This film captures the dreams and desperation of the 60s like few others, and you emerge from it changed; it’s a life experience as much as a film experience. Rivette’s obsessional uses of real time and natural duration take some getting used to, but the experience becomes both mesmerizing and all-enveloping.” Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum. Chicago Reader. Online. http://onfilm.chireader.com/

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jacques Rivette, Marilu Parolini ; photography, Etienne Becker, Alain Levent ; music, Jean-Claude Eloy.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Josee Destoop, Celia, Andre S.-Labarthe.

results.title: L'amour D'une Femme = the Love of a Woman
results.brief_description:
Marie, a young doctor, is setting up practice on the Island of Ouessant (off the coast of Brittany). Marie must first overcome the local male population’s built-in misogyny. Gradually, she convinces everyone that she’s as qualified for her job as any man. She shares her time between her work and Ms. Leblanc, a retired schoolteacher, with whom she has become friends. When Andre, an engineeer, arrives on the island, the equilibrium of Marie’s life is upset. This was Jean Gremillon’s last film. One of the least known of the great French directors of the 1930s, Gremillon is possibly the most ‘classic’ in his combination of realism and popular genres. Gremillon’s atmospheric realism, especially his depictions of social milieux (typographers, seamen, the provincial bourgeoisie), echoed his definition that ‘it is a question not of mechanical naturalism, but, rather, of the beauty in achieving the maximum of expression within the maximum of order.’ He also, unusually, offered portraits of remarkably strong women in ‘Le ciel est a vous’ and ‘L’amour d’une femme’, feminist heroines ‘avant la lettre’, struggling equally with work and love.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The Companion to French Cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Gerin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Rene Fallet, Rene Wheeler ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Henri Dutilleux ; editor, Margueritte Renoir.
Cast: Micheline Presle, Massimo Girotti, Gaby Morlay, Julien Carette, Maude Siame.

Gremillon’s atmospheric realism, especially his depictions of social milieux (typographers, seamen, the provincial bourgeoisie), echoed his definition that ‘it is a question not of mechanical naturalism, but, rather, of the beauty in achieving the maximum of expression within the maximum of order.’ He also, unusually, offered portraits of remarkably strong women in ‘Le ciel est a vous’ and ‘L’amour d’une femme’, feminist heroines ‘avant la lettre’, struggling equally with work and love.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The Companion to French Cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Gerin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Rene Fallet, Rene Wheeler ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Henri Dutilleux ; editor, Margueritte Renoir.
Cast: Micheline Presle, Massimo Girotti, Gaby Morlay, Julien Carette, Maude Siame.
